title: Edmonton Obesity Staging System (EOSS)
description: Stratifies the presence and severity of obesity-related health impairments across medical, functional, and psychological domains to guide treatment decisions and predict outcomes.

parameters.name: obesity_risk_factors
parameters.description: Obesity-related medical risk factors and comorbidities
options: Stage 1: Subclinical risk factors (borderline hypertension, impaired fasting glucose, elevated liver enzymes, arthralgia)
Stage 2: Established obesity-related chronic disease (hypertension, type 2 diabetes, sleep apnea, osteoarthritis, reflux disease, gallbladder disease, gout)
Stage 3: End-organ damage (myocardial infarction, heart failure, diabetic complications, osteoarthritis requiring joint replacement, non-alcoholic steatohepatitis)
Stage 4: Severe, potentially end-stage chronic disease (advanced heart failure, stroke, severe diabetic complications, severe osteoarthritis, cirrhosis)

parameters.name: physical_symptoms
parameters.description: Physical symptoms and functional limitations related to obesity
options: Stage 0: No physical symptoms or functional limitations
Stage 1: Mild physical symptoms or limitations with activities of daily living
Stage 2: Moderate physical symptoms or limitations with activities of daily living
Stage 3: Significant physical symptoms or limitations with activities of daily living
Stage 4: Severe physical symptoms or limitations with activities of daily living

parameters.name: psychological_symptoms
parameters.description: Psychological symptoms and mental health impact related to obesity
options: Stage 0: No psychological symptoms or mental health impact
Stage 1: Mild psychological symptoms or mental health impact
Stage 2: Moderate psychological symptoms or mental health impact
Stage 3: Significant psychological symptoms or mental health impact
Stage 4: Severe psychological symptoms or mental health impact

result.name: eoss_stage
result.description: Edmonton Obesity Staging System stage (0-4) determined by highest severity across all domains

ranges.interpretation: No obesity-related health impairments present. Focus on lifestyle counseling for healthy eating, regular physical activity, and weight maintenance. Prevention strategies to avoid future obesity-related complications.

Mild obesity-related health impairments. Investigate and monitor subclinical risk factors. Implement intensive lifestyle interventions including structured dietary counseling, exercise programs, and behavioral modification. Regular monitoring for progression of risk factors.

Moderate obesity-related health impairments with established chronic disease. Initiate comprehensive obesity treatment including pharmacotherapy consideration if appropriate. Actively manage comorbidities and functional limitations. Consider referral to obesity specialist.

Severe obesity-related health impairments with end-organ damage or significant functional impairment. Aggressive obesity management required including consideration of bariatric surgery if appropriate. Intensive management of comorbidities and psychological support. Multidisciplinary care team approach.

End-stage obesity-related health impairments with severe, potentially life-threatening conditions. Pursue most aggressive management options available including bariatric surgery evaluation. Palliative care considerations may be appropriate. Comprehensive support services and end-of-life planning discussions if indicated.

references: Sharma AM, Kushner RF. A proposed clinical staging system for obesity. Int J Obes (Lond). 2009;33(3):289-95. doi: 10.1038/ijo.2009.2.

Padwal RS, Pajewski NM, Allison DB, Sharma AM. Using the Edmonton obesity staging system to predict mortality in a population-representative cohort of people with overweight and obesity. CMAJ. 2011;183(14):E1059-66. doi: 10.1503/cmaj.110387.

Aasheim ET, Aylwin SJ, Radhakrishnan ST, Sood AS, Jovanovic Z, Olbers T, et al. Assessment of Obesity Beyond Body Mass Index to Guide Treatment. Curr Cardiol Rep. 2017;19(5):33. doi: 10.1007/s11886-017-0849-1.

Canning KL, Brown RE, Jamnik VK, Salmon A, Ardern CI, Kuk JL. Individuals with obesity and type 2 diabetes have additional immune dysfunction compared with obese individuals who are metabolically healthy. BMJ Open Diabetes Res Care. 2017;5(1):e000379. doi: 10.1136/bmjdrc-2016-000379.
formula: EOSS Stage = max(obesity_risk_factors, physical_symptoms, psychological_symptoms). The highest stage rating across all three domains determines the final EOSS stage.
notes: The EOSS provides a more comprehensive assessment of obesity-related health risk than BMI alone.
The system evaluates obesity across three key domains: medical risk factors, physical function, and psychological health.
Each domain is independently assessed and scored from 0-4, with the highest score determining the overall stage.
Stage determination is based on the most severe impairment across any domain, not an average.
Higher EOSS stages are associated with increased mortality risk independent of BMI.
The system can help guide treatment intensity and resource allocation for obesity management.
EOSS staging has been validated for predicting surgical outcomes and long-term mortality.
The tool is designed to be used in conjunction with, not as a replacement for, BMI classification.
Clinical assessment should consider individual patient factors beyond EOSS staging.
Regular reassessment is recommended as obesity-related health status may change over time.
The system can help identify patients who may benefit from more aggressive interventions.
EOSS staging may be particularly useful for prioritizing patients for bariatric surgery evaluation.
The framework encourages comprehensive evaluation of obesity-related health impacts.
Patients with higher EOSS stages require more intensive, multidisciplinary management approaches.
